trigger_event: After exposing years of deliberate deprivation in low-score zones, Rada receives evidence of even deeper abuses and faces enormous public pressure to guide the city’s next move.
dilemma: Should Rada force the Council to hold a public Truth Tribunal that could air every hidden BCI crime, or bypass authority completely and spark an unfiltered grassroots data hunt guided by her clues? Each path could either transform Stenograd—or plunge it further into chaos.
reason: Rada is torn: her role as a journalist calls for open reckoning, but as a rebel and survivor of system abuses, she doubts whether official processes can ever be trusted. The city is primed for upheaval—her decision will set the course for either collective healing or uncontrolled exposure.
choice_a: Push the Council into launching a public Truth Tribunal, demanding formal citizen testimony and institutional accountability.
belief_a: Testimony in the public eye can heal collective wounds and legitimize change.
History, once spoken aloud, can't be erased by sabotage or denial.
Even a flawed process can spark reckoning if enough light is shined on it.
choice_b: Inspire the public to uncover hidden BCI history through cryptic broadcasts and grassroots action, fueling a decentralized hunt for evidence outside any official process.
belief_b: Truth belongs to the people, not to council chambers or official archives.
Real justice is made in the streets and networks, not in monitored halls.
Only unstoppable, collective action can break the cycle of cover-ups.
